Projet regional de biosecurite en
            Afrique de l'Ouest (UEMOA) : cadre de gestion

trustfund:
TF056101-GEF PDF B-AFRICA: WEST AFRICA
            BIOSAFETY PROJECT PDF B

abstracts.cdata!:
The West Africa Regional Biosafety
            Project builds capacity for risk assessment of transgenic
            crops, particularly Bt-cotton. While the potential benefits
            of Bt-cotton includes improved yields, decreased pesticide
            use, and labor savings, the potential impacts upon the local
            environment and the socioeconomic fabric of the region needs
            to be assessed. This environmental impact assessment focuses
            on biodiversity, insect resistance management, and the
            co-existence of different production systems. The assessment
            regarding biosafety involves evaluating the extent of gene
            flow and the potential displacement of native strains or
            non-target plant species. Insect resistance management
            assessment will compare bollworm damage to other types of
            insect damage to guide pesticide applications for Bt-cotton,
            and it will also address the issue of refugia (areas
            reserved for target species) and the capacity of the
            extension service to train farmers in agronomic practices
            involving Bt cotton. Also the interest of certain countries
            in organic cotton production and different production
            systems will also be assessed. An assessment of the
            socioeconomic impact will focus on seed pricing, the risk of
            farmer dependency on monopolistic suppliers, and issues
            concerning intellectual property rights. Capacity will be
            improved among extension services and farmer organizations
            to increase knowledge of the technical issues involved,
            including seed price negotiations. In addition, specific
            attention will be directed to support the countries in
            registering varieties and in negotiating licenses for
            intellectual property rights.
